ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned thermodynamics, about entropy, and how various thermodynamical cycles work (Carnot, Otto, Diesel, Rankine)

I learned about thermodynamic principles such as the laws of thermodynamics, entropy, mass and energy balances, etc. as they apply to engineering phenomena such as the various power cycles (Stirling, Carnot, etc.) and thermodynamic devices (including nozzles, turbines, heat exchangers, etc.).

This course gave an excellent overview of thermodynamic concepts for mechanical engineers. I feel like everything really came together at the end and I understood how all of the topics we learned fit together. I also appreciated the emphasis on engines and power plants, as I now feel I really understand how these work.
I learned how to evaluate thermodynamic systems and cycles

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Lectures were engaging and workload was fair. Professor was very accessible and knowledgeable.
Weaknesses: Review sessions would have been great for the tests.

The course was well organized and included an important practical element: The Stirling Engine. This is extremely important since the course is designed for engineering majors. I do wish that we could have worked on the Stirling Engine together or had practical work done as a class lead by the lecturer in a lab to prepare for this final project.

The material in this course is very dense and there's a lot to cover, but it was well-organized and taught in as interesting a way as possible. I think more example problems in class would be helpful, as a lot of time was spent on derivations which we sometimes used but often did not, but I think this is a trade off of Cong's emphasis on understanding rather than problem solving.
Lectures were pretty clear, but lacked examples of the concepts being taught, making the homeworks fairly difficult.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would if you need to or wish to learn thermodynamics. There are a couple other options though which one should consider and see which is best for them.
Yes, particularly with Professor Cong Su. The course is extremely interesting and leads an engineering-approach to thermodynamic studies.
Yes. You probably need to take this if you are taking it, but especially with Cong as a professor, it's taught interestingly and with a lot of care.

This course was one of the best I have taken as a mechanical engineering major here at Yale. There is definitely a lot of material covered, but it feels organized, and it is relatively easy to absorb it, and it feels like you have learnt a ton by the end of the semester. Only problem was the stirling engine contest that was part of the grade, and almost no one could make it work. Definitely suggest this class.
You most likely are required to take this course as a mechanical engineering major, but the content is interesting and Professor Su did a good job teaching the material.
